The 2019 British pavilion at the Venice Biennale was canceled last month after a British artist, Nusseibeh Darwa, was detained by British police for throwing a set of burning embers toward the pavilion during a protest over the filming of a controversial UK drone strike on a Turkish military compound. The incident took place on May 30, an English day, which is considered a day of rest in Islam. The British artist was taken to a police station for questioning, but he was not charged.Darwa was charged with one count of criminal damage, but his conviction was thrown out following a retrial after a jury found that he had been unlawfully arrested and had his rights violated. His lawyers had claimed that the questioning of the artist had been coerced. In his retrial, the artist was found guilty of seven charges, but only one of the counts was ultimately proved.The case has sparked outrage across the UK and beyond; British prime minister Boris Johnson called the event cancelled because of the protest an attack on freedom of the press.
